question: In mouse models of MOZ-TIF2–induced acute myeloid leukemia, does genetic loss of CSF1R increase leukemogenesis (e.g., higher leukemia-initiating activity or faster disease progression) compared with CSF1R-sufficient mice? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Moreover, induction of AML was suppressed in CSF1R-deficient mice and CSF1R inhibitors slowed the progression of MOZ-TIF2–induced leukemia.
content.source_2: In transplantation assays, CSF1Rlow fractions, rather than CSF1Rhigh cells, exhibited the most robust leukemia-initiating capacity in the MOZ-TIF2 context.
content.source_3: Contrary to PU.1-dependent models, leukemia stem cells localized predominantly to CSF1Rlow compartments, and experimental downregulation or pharmacologic inhibition of CSF1R accelerated MOZ-TIF2-driven AML onset in mice.
